fields.description: When the Macbook pro restarts, the SSH is not working to push the commits to Bitbucket. It says permission denied no public key. I have found a workaround which is deleting ssh keys generated from the local environment and Bitbucket account, and remove the added account on Sourcetree application. After removing the account, I tried to create a new one with OAuth (Google Sign-in) and it authenticated successfully, however it doesn't redirect to the Sourcetree application and adds the account. It just goes to my Bitbucket account page like it is a regular web browser. Hence, I have to click cancel to try again but it never works. As a result, I'm stuck with my commits in the local environment and can't push them.
fields.summary: Cannot add account with OAuth after Mac restart

fields.description:
I'm unable to connect my Bitbucket account in SourceTree.
 # I start SourceTree, choose File->Settings->Accounts, or choose "Accounts..." from the drop-down in my repositories list.
 # I choose "Add..." with Host: Bitbucket, Auth Type: OAuth, Protocol: SSH, and then "Connect Account."
 # A browser window appears, saying "Please sign into this account:"  I've tried both checking and unchecking "Stay signed into this account" with the same outcome.  I enter my email and password and "Log in."
 # A spinner appears at window center and another next to the Cancel button.  When they stop, the Bitbucket webpage shows "Your work" and contains my repo.  I can navigate around this page.  There is only a Cancel button at bottom of the window, so I can't proceed to log in.

This sounds very similar to SRCTREE-5393 except there is no infinite loop.

Prior to entering this state, I logged into Bitbucket with Chrome and created a repo. I chose "Clone in SourceTree," and then canceled out of the dialog that opened in SourceTree.

fields.description:
Sourcetree generates or adds to a config file in the users .ssh directory.  The default text is something like (don't remember the exact Host)

 
{code:java}
--- Sourcetree Generated ---
Host account-name@github.com
        HostName github.com
        User username
        PreferredAuthentications publickey
        IdentityFile /Users/matt/.ssh/keyname
        UseKeychain yes
        AddKeysToAgent yes
# ----------------------------
{code}
 

However, GitHub requires that you use SSH with git as the user.  So the above config tells Sourcetree to use your GitHub username which results in permission denied.  Changing the ~/.ssh/config file to the below code allowed me to clone my repositories from GitHub.  I'm not sure if changing the Host to github.com is required as well, but it works so I'm not messing with it!

 
{code:java}
--- Sourcetree Generated ---
Host github.com
        HostName github.com
        User git
        PreferredAuthentications publickey
        IdentityFile /Users/matt/.ssh/keyname
        UseKeychain yes
        AddKeysToAgent yes
# ----------------------------
{code}
fields.summary: Sourcetree creates incorrect SSH config file for GitHub account

fields.description:
I didn't find an open issue for that. The issue is I add a remote "upstream" and it's spelt everywhere properly except in the "Track Remote Branch" option when I right click a local branch. There it's spelt "Upstream" with an uppercase "U" so when I try to set one of those branches I get an error.

So the steps are:
 * "New remote"
 * Remote name: upstream (+url, host etc.)
 * Right click on a local branch
 * "Track Remote Branch"
 * origin is all lowercase, Upstream has the "U" in uppercase
 * Click on a Upstream one
 * Get error: "fatal: Cannot setup tracking information; starting point 'Upstream/master' is not a branch."

So anytime I pull I have to manually change the repository (there it's properly spelt "uppercase") then refresh then pick the branch then reselect "Rebase instead of merge" as it gets unselected when the repository is changed then "OK"
fields.summary: Upstream is spelt with an upper case "U" then can't be set as a Remote Branch

fields.description:

To replicate, simply modify a version-controlled file, and open its repo in SourceTree: SourceTree will show the modification in its diff-pane, and yet r-clicking the file and selecting 'External Diff' does nothing; i.e. no error-message is shown, nor does the external-diff tool get launched/opened.

 

My configuration:

SourceTree pref -> Diff: External-Diff/Merge setup as follows:

Visual Diff Tool: Custom

Diff Command: /usr/local/bin/bcomp

Diff Command Arguments: $LOCAL $REMOTE

Merge Tool: custom

Merge Command: /usr/local/bin/bcomp

Merge Command Arguments: $LOCAL $REMOTE $BASE $MERGED
fields.summary: External diff broken in sourcetree 2.7.6-177

fields.description:
Proposal :

In order to help beginners to avoid work loss, upon new branch creation sourcetree could suggest to the user to push the new branch on the remote (when one or more remotes are declared in the repository).

 

Motivation:

Indeed, beginners are often not so familiar with the working copy, staging area and the remote notions.

This can lead to work loss in some cases : a user creates a branch to make a snapshot, go back to the original branch to make some modifications, deletions  ... then he gets back on the new branch and works on it. One or several weeks later, its computer meets a crash.

At this moment, the user realizes the snapshot branch he has working on during the last weeks was only a local branch.

 

Solution:

A popup upon branch creation could ask the user if its will is really to create a local branch, or if the branch should be published on a remote.
fields.summary: Ask the user to push on remote upon new branch creation

fields.description:
There was an argument injection vulnerability in Sourcetree for macOS via filenames in Mercurial repositories. An attacker with permission to commit to a Mercurial repository linked in Sourcetree for macOS is able to exploit this issue to gain code execution on the system.

*Affected versions:*
 * Versions of Sourcetree for macOS from 1.0b2 before 2.7.6 are affected by this vulnerability.

*Fix:*
 * Upgrade Sourcetree for macOS to version 2.7.6 or higher from [https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/] .

For additional details, see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/4erXO].
fields.summary: Argument injection via Mercurial repository filenames - CVE-2018-13385

fields.description:
The embedded version of Git used in Sourcetree for macOS was vulnerable to CVE-2018-11235. An attacker can exploit this issue if they can commit to a Git repository linked in Sourcetree for macOS that has been recursively cloned or if a user interacts with a submodule. This allows them to execute arbitrary code on systems running a vulnerable version of Sourcetree for macOS.

*Affected versions:*
 * Versions of Sourcetree for Mac from 1.0b2 before 2.7.4 are affected by this vulnerability.

*Fix:*
 * Upgrade Sourcetree for macOS to version 2.7.4 or higher from [https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/] .

For additional details, see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/4erXO].
fields.summary: Git submodules vulnerability - CVE-2018-11235

fields.description:
Untracked files appear in the File status in the Unstaged files widget. When staging an untracked file ({{git add -N <filename>}}), the file disappears from both the Unstaged files _and_ Staged files widgets.
h4. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new repository and open it in the SourceTree client
# From the command line, change directory to the repo and create a new file with some content in it
# Confirm the file is showing in SourceTree by clicking on File status and pressing {{⌘+R}}
# Add the file with an intent to stage later by running {{git add -N <filename>}}
# Refresh the SourceTree window by pressing {{⌘+R}}

h4. Expected Results

The file should be showing in the Staged files widget as a new file with no content. The file should _also_ be showing in the Unstaged files as a _modified_ file with all content counting as a diff from the staged version of the file with zero content.

h4. Actual Results

The file does not show up in either widget.
fields.summary: Files Added With Intent To Stage Disappear From File Status Widget

fields.description:
I work on an enormous project with many remote branches, and many, many remote tags.  I'm not interested in looking at the many commit nodes that terminate in only a remote tag, of which I have no concern.  In a perhaps related issue, SourceTree is very, very slow on this project, SPODing for 30 seconds at a time.

Much like the "Show/Hide Remote Branches" dropdown, I would like to see a "Show/Hide Remote Tags" dropdown.  (Perhaps alternatively it's a dropbox with two checkboxes, branches, and tags)

The point is that only for this one project, my commit view is cluttered with lots of tags I don't care about, and Sourcetree performance is very slow.  I'd ideally like to see only my local branches and tags, and their ancestors.  Any commits that culminate in only remote tags - the whole commit would be hidden.  This would follow very similarly to the existing behavior of the "Hide Remote Branches", where any commits that culminate in only remote branches.

Thanks for your consideration.
fields.summary: Add ability to "Hide Remote Tags" and commits a la Remote Branches

fields.description:
In SourceTree Settings > General. "Use Mac OS windows restoration" should be default if not the only option. Your default option is Restore windows on startup.

I do prefer to restore windows but your own window restoration is slow, I gain startup time increase as soon as I switched to the Mac OS windows restoration.

Mac behaviour can be changed by user every time when quitting app with option key modifier. Windows restoration also can be enabled or disabled in Mac OS System Preferences.
fields.summary: Incorrect Default for Window Restoration

This text is over 72 characters and I want it to break into a new line below this one to
 
#Example Tasks related
This is my task related info, closes #issue or similar
bind it to the guidelines; 
{code}
I'd also like to see a guideline specific for the first line, for those who wish to use 50/72 standard (this guideline would only be visual, not working like the actual format)
fields.summary: Git commit template with guideline format

fields.description:
When committing changes, I usually close folders which aren't relevant, so I get a clear focus on which files to review and stage:

!image-2018-06-21-19-05-51-147.png!

Please notice that "pear" and "public" are folded intentionally.

When I'm staging "contacts.jinja2", I would expect SourceTree to jump to the closes available unstaged file within unfolded trees, which would be "dom_list.tpl".

Unfortunately, since a recent update, SourceTree doesn't look for the next, but the previous unstaged file and even unfolds a folded tree to do so:

!image-2018-06-21-19-09-15-131.png!

Please notice, that "public" is now unintentionally unfolded (while "pear" is not). This is super annoying and this didn't happen in SourceTree for the longest time I'm working with it.
fields.summary: Folded subtrees should not unfold unless I unfold them

[https://twitter.com/ytbryan/status/1009619363022815233]

 

Can we allow sort by timestamp? 

!image-2018-06-21-23-36-24-013.png!

add option to skip git hooks in push, commit (--no-verify)

fields.description:
Steps:
 * select a several adjacent commits (n>2)
 * open context menu, choose `Cherry Pick`
 * stay in confirmation dialog for a while until background refresh takes place
 * see: only first and last commits get selected
 * if you didn't pay your attention to that fact you'd likely cherry-pick first & last commits instead of initially selected ones

The issue persists for a long time.

Very annoying to me because I often makes cherry-picks commits in bulk.
fields.summary: Background history refresh ruins selection

fields.description:
The *Check default remotes for updates every X minutes* checkbox in global preferences no longer seems to work after a recent SourceTree upgrade (I upgrade fairly regularly, so it would have been a recent change within the last month or two at most).  Repositories will fetch latest changes from all remotes anyway when they are opened, irregardless of the preference.  Curiously, the per-repository *Refresh remote status in the background (if enabled in global preferences)* checkbox can be unchecked, and then auto-fetching no longer occurs.  However, it's cumbersome to have to uncheck this for every repository.  I would prefer that the global preference be honored instead.

Steps to reproduce:
# Uncheck the *Check default remotes for updates every X minutes* checkbox from global preferences.
# Open the *Tasks Monitor* debug window.
# Open a repository.

*Expected behavior*: No repository fetching should occur.
*Actual behavior*: Observe that a "Fetch" task was run in the tasks monitor, and the latest remote branches have been fetched.

*Workaround*: go to per-repository Settings, and uncheck *Refresh remote status in the background (if enabled in global preferences)*.  Now, fetching does not occur.  However, it's an annoying workaround because I have to do it for every repository and I'd rather have it apply globally.

(NOTE:  I am assuming the *if enabled in global preferences* phrase in per-repository settings refers to the global *Check default remotes for updates every X minutes* checkbox in the global settings.......)
fields.summary: "Check default remotes for updates every X minutes" in global preferences no longer works

fields.summary: Keeps crashing on 10.13.4

fields.description:
i create empty git repo on Bitbucket

then try to clone it with sourcetree

app is crashed. after restart its ask me reopen or not windows, but anyway reopen and crash again. a had about half second before crash every time, in this time i deleted new repo from list, but crash not gone.

i try downgrade app version, one by one. crash stopped only with 2.3.2, and if update to actual version, crash returns
fields.summary: always crash after trying to add repo from bitbucket

fields.description: I installed the latest update for SourceTree when prompted to update. Now I am unable to to launch the app. It crashes within 1-2 seconds of opening.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when trying to open after latest update

fields.description:
Using SourceTree without issue all day as usual. Got a notification that a new version was available and went through the usual process of downloading/installing/restarting. New version opened long enough to show my repo list and open the project I was working on then the app closed. This repeats each time I open, no error, no crash warning, just closes.

Have restarted the machine and tried reinstalling back to v2.7 but no luck. Same result every time in every version.

Pleas advise if you can. Life is too short for GIT on the command line :(

 

PS - Don't really know what I'm supposed to be submitting on this page so shout if you need more details or anything.

 

Thanks
fields.summary: Latest update (2.7.4) crashes on launch (Mac 10.11.6)

fields.description: Startup fails with an immediate crash.
fields.summary: App crashes on startup
Better "Open in Terminal" implementation

fields.description:
# Create a new repository:
    {code:bash}
    mkdir test; cd test; git init; touch .gitignore; git add .gitignore; git commit -m "Init."{code}
 # Add repository to SourceTree.
 # In SourceTree window for that repository, click Settings.
 # In Settings modal, click Remotes tab.
 # See an origin with no path. Click Edit for it.
 # Enter a URL ({{ssh://git@<domain>/<path>}}).
 # Click OK.
 # Attempt a push. It fails.
 # Look back in remote settings, and see that your change wasn't saved.
fields.summary: edit remote fails silently
Sourcetree does not ask for GPG passphrase to sign git commits

fields.description:
Cardinal sin reporting two potential issues in one bug report.  Sorry about that but it is about the experience!

I had to go through about 12 pages of images prior to finally being able to register for SourceTree.  When I clicked on the confirmation email, I was returned JSON to the browser.

In my opinion, both are not optimum experiences.
fields.summary: Numerous Capture Images prior to registration and JSON response when confirming email
SourceTree is using up user's CPU

fields.description:
At the moment in order to delete a local branch you have to select the branch in the workspace and right-click it to bring up a context menu, from which you can then select "Delete feature/xyz...".

This is awkward when you want to clean up several deleted branches.

Can we PLEASE simply support the delete (Backspace on OSX) key? It's going to display a modal to proceed regardless, so it's not like we're going to be accidentally deleting branches left and right.

 

(Although also supporting Command-Delete in order to bypass the dialog would be a nice option.)
fields.summary: Add Delete key/command key for branches

fields.description:
Step 1. Open mobile application "Железнодорожные билеты" keeping device in vertical position - Route page appears as a start page 

Step 2. Turn the device to the horizontal position - *unconnected logically message* "You have no unused tickets" appears and text "Rotate your device upright for further work with the application" 

Step 3. Touch any place on the screen, slide the screen left, right, up/down - the application is unable to run any functions when device is in the horizontal position
fields.summary: Mobile application "Железнодорожные билеты " (Version 1.8) is disabled when device in the horizontal position; testing device HTC One Duo Sim, 5 inch, Android 5.0.2; Ukr, Rus, Eng tested with the same result

fields.description:
When you enter the wrong name of the settlement there is no error message.

Steps for reproduse:

1. Log in to the application "Залізничні квитки ПАТ "Укрзалізниця"

2. Choose "Buy tickets" in the menu

3. Input: From *Kyiv* To *Budapest*.

The name "*Budapest"* is not correct because it is not in the drop down list.

The application does not allow you to move on to the next step and does not respond to this error. There are no reports of incorrect data entry.
fields.summary: Incorrectly input of settlement on mobile app Ukrzaliznytsya

fields.description:
Шаги воспроизведения:

1. Открываем главную страницу сайта http://nibulon.com/
2. Выбираем из меню категорию "Закупівля сільгосппродукції/Калькулятор знижок"
3. В поля "Показники", вводим числа для факта, при которых факт = базис + до 1%.
4. Нажимаем кнопку "Розрахувати".
Ожидаемый результат: числовой результат с корректным округлением до двух знаков после запятой.

Фактический результат: отображается числовой результат с некорректным округлением до двух знаков после запятой.
fields.summary: некорректное округление результата при факт = базис + до 1%

fields.description:
Шаги воспроизведения:

1. Открываем главную страницу сайта http://nibulon.com/
2. Выбираем из меню категорию "Закупівля сільгосппродукції/Калькулятор знижок"
3. В поля "Показники", вводим положительные числа для факта, которые > базиса.
4. Нажимаем кнопку "Розрахувати".
Ожидаемый результат: корректный результат после произведения математических действий по формуле Дюваля с такими исходными вводимыми числами.

Фактический результат: отображается результат "0,00" в числовом процентном формате.

fields.description:
Hi all, long time listener, first time caller - [Brian Ganninger|https://twitter.com/bgannin] mentioned I should drop by after a tweet. 

I'm liking the in-app notifications for BB pipeline runs in the latest SourceTree (Mac OS); it'd be very cool if we could see a list of pipeline run histories (and pending/success/fail state) in the SourceTree app, rather than needing to pop to bitbucket.org to check in on it..

Otherwise: I'd like to take this little moment to congratulations you on a fantastic product, keep up the great work.

 

PG
fields.summary: See pipelines run history in SourceTree
